models package

module:

models.__init__

synopsis:

Convenience re-exports for domain models (Student, Course, Instructor, Person).

This package models exposes the main domain classes so other modules can import them directly from models instead of digging into individual files.

Notes

  • This is just an import aggregator (aka “barrel”) for nicer imports in the app.

  • Keeping __all__ explicit so Sphinx + linters know what we intend to export.

  • No logic here, literally just re-exports.

class models.Course(course_id: str, course_name: str, instructor: Instructor | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

Course model representing a single course offering.

Parameters:

  • course_id (str) – External identifier of the course (validated, normalized).

  • course_name (str) – Human-readable course title (validated, normalized).

  • instructor (Instructor, optional) – The instructor initially assigned to this course (can be None).

course_id

Normalized course ID (e.g., uppercased or trimmed).

Type:

str

course_name

Normalized course name.

Type:

str

instructor

Current instructor or None if unassigned.

Type:

Instructor or None

enrolled_students

List of students registered in this course.

Type:

list[Student]

Notes

  • __slots__ is used to keep the objects lightweight (and catch typos).

  • Relationship updates call corresponding “local” helpers to avoid recursion.

add_student(student: Student) → None[source]

Public API to enroll a student and sync the inverse relation.

Parameters:

student (Student) – Student to enroll in this course.

Return type:

None

Notes

  • Prevents duplicates.

  • Ensures the student’s registered_courses includes this course.

course_id
course_name
enrolled_students: list[Student]
classmethod from_dict(d: dict) → Course[source]

Construct a course from a dictionary (instructor is not attached here).

Parameters:

d (dict) – Dictionary with at least course_id and course_name.

Returns:

New Course instance with no instructor assigned yet.

Return type:

Course

Notes

  • The instructor is intentionally set to None; attach it later if needed.

instructor
remove_student(student: Student) → None[source]

Remove a student and clean up the inverse link if present.

Parameters:

student (Student) – Student to remove from enrollment.

Return type:

None

set_instructor(instructor: Instructor | None) → None[source]

Assign or clear the instructor and keep both sides in sync.

Parameters:

instructor (Instructor or None) – New instructor to assign or None to unassign.

Return type:

None

Notes

  • If setting to None, the old instructor (if any) loses this course.

  • If assigning a new instructor, the previous one is updated accordingly.

  • Early-return if the instructor is unchanged.

to_dict() → dict[source]

Serialize the course to a plain dictionary.

Returns:

Dict with keys: course_id, course_name, instructor_id, and enrolled_student_ids.

Return type:

dict

Notes

  • IDs only for related objects (keeps payload small).

class models.Instructor(name: str, age: int, email: str, instructor_id: str)[source]

Bases: Person

Instructor model; inherits name/age/email from Person and adds an ID plus the list of assigned courses.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Instructor’s name (validated in Person).

  • age (int) – Instructor’s age (validated in Person).

  • email (str) – Instructor’s email (validated in Person).

  • instructor_id (str) – External identifier for the instructor (validated, normalized).

instructor_id

Normalized instructor ID (e.g., trimmed/uppercased by norm_id).

Type:

str

assigned_courses

Courses currently assigned to this instructor.

Type:

list[Course]

Notes

  • Keep list maintenance simple; we call “local” helpers to avoid loops.

assign_course(course: Course) → None[source]

Assign a course to this instructor and sync the inverse relation.

Parameters:

course (Course) – Course to assign (ignored if falsy).

Return type:

None

Notes

  • Prevents duplicates in assigned_courses.

  • Ensures course.instructor points to self.

  • Cleans up the old instructor if the course was previously assigned.

assigned_courses: list['Course']
classmethod from_dict(d: dict) → Instructor[source]

Construct an Instructor from a dictionary.

Parameters:

d (dict) – Dictionary containing at least name, age, email, and instructor_id.

Returns:

New Instructor instance (courses are not attached here).

Return type:

Instructor

Notes

  • Courses are intentionally not wired here; attach them later as needed.

instructor_id
list_assigned_courses() → str[source]

Return a human-readable string of assigned course IDs (also prints it).

Returns:

Message of the form: "The instructor <name> of id <instructor_id> is assigned to the following courses: <ids>"

Return type:

str

Notes

  • Also prints the same message for convenience during manual testing.

  • If there are no courses, returns “no courses”.

to_dict() → dict[source]

Serialize the instructor to a plain dictionary.

Returns:

Dict with person fields + instructor_id and assigned_course_ids.

Return type:

dict

Notes

  • Related objects are represented by their IDs only.

class models.Person(name: str, age: int, email: str)[source]

Bases: object

Simple person record with name, age, and email (normalized).

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Person’s name (validated, then normalized).

  • age (int) – Non-negative integer age.

  • email (str) – Email address (validated, then normalized).

name

Normalized person name.

Type:

str

age

Integer age (stored as int explicitly).

Type:

int

_email

Backing field for the public email property.

Type:

str

Notes

  • __slots__ used to save memory and avoid accidental attributes.

  • Email is exposed via a property so we can re-validate on update.

age
property email: str

Email getter.

Returns:

The (normalized) email string.

Return type:

str

introduce() → str[source]

Return and print a small intro string (lab-style helper).

Returns:

A message of the form: "Hi, I'm <name>. I am <age> years old. Please find attached my email address if you wish to contact me: <email>"

Return type:

str

Notes

  • Also prints to stdout because it’s handy for quick manual checks.

name
class models.Student(name: str, age: int, email: str, student_id: str)[source]

Bases: Person

Student model; inherits name/age/email from Person and adds a student ID plus the list of registered courses.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Student’s name (validated in Person).

  • age (int) – Student’s age (validated in Person).

  • email (str) – Student’s email (validated in Person).

  • student_id (str) – External identifier for the student (validated, normalized).

student_id

Normalized student ID (via norm_id).

Type:

str

registered_courses

Courses this student is currently registered in.

Type:

list[Course]

Notes

  • Relationship maintenance tries to be simple and explicit.

classmethod from_dict(d: dict) → Student[source]

Construct a Student from a dictionary.

Parameters:

d (dict) – Dictionary containing at least name, age, email, and student_id.

Returns:

New Student instance (courses are not attached here).

Return type:

Student

Notes

  • Courses are intentionally not wired here; attach them later if needed.

list_registered_courses() → str[source]

Return a human-readable string of registered course IDs (also prints it).

Returns:

Message of the form: "The student <name> of id <student_id> is registered in the following courses: <ids>"

Return type:

str

Notes

  • Also prints the same message for quick manual checking.

  • If none, shows “no courses”.

register_course(course: Course) → None[source]

Register this student into a course and sync the inverse relation.

Parameters:

course (Course) – Course to register in (ignored if falsy).

Return type:

None

Notes

  • Prevents duplicates in registered_courses.

  • Ensures course.enrolled_students includes this student.

registered_courses: list['Course']
student_id
to_dict() → dict[source]

Serialize the student to a plain dictionary.

Returns:

Dict with person fields + student_id and registered_course_ids.

Return type:

dict

Notes

  • Related objects are represented by their IDs only.

unregister_course(course: Course) → None[source]

Unregister this student from a course and clean up the inverse link.

Parameters:

course (Course) – Course to remove.

Return type:

None
